text:
I'm new to hubl but a 20 year coder. I'm missing something with hubl comparisons. When I set a value to 1 during a test, a compare of a == 1 returns true.

However, when I use a live value during an email template render with a value that contains 1, the same compare of a == 1 returns false.

When I output the contents of the live variable on the screen it indeed says it contains 1.

Does anyone know what I'm missing?

Hi,
I'm new to Hubl,  how can i add a simple icon to the navbar menu ?
you’ll want to use css for that
If you're using something like FontAwesome or the like, you should be able to use span tags inside of the label for the menu item.
are you possibly comparing a string and an int? the `pprint` filter might help debug <https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs/hubl/hubl-supported-filters#pprint>
<@U2H3TT8F2> I've used that solution many rimes
Times
Likewise

<@U2H3TT8F2> thanks!
actually I want to add a search icon to stand on it's own (which will open modal with a search field). As I understand your answer it needs a menu item to work.
Is it correct?

You might be able to do this via the menu system (depending on the modal you are using) but this seems like it might be easier to add this into the header as a separate item (custom module) that would then trigger your modal.
reason being, if you do this in the menu, then have a mobile menu, you would be hiding the search button which may be something you want to have on mobile.
<@U2H3TT8F2> Yes on mobile the icon will be hidden within the menu. Can I add it differently than the advance menu ? Using :after won't work because it isn't clickable
You should be able to create a custom module to add it in as well. What icon library are you using? or is it a custom icon?
it will be clickable if it is from the anchor link
Likewise, you could probably just use the SVG of the icon and place that in the label of the advanced menus. Then you wouldnt have to use the ::after

Not sure what you mean when you say "place that in the label of the advance menu" here i'm looking:
<https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs/hubl/hubl-supported-tags>  -> menu
I might be missing smth as i'm totally new it.
I'm using Fontawesome btw
Thanks for your help appreciate it !
You would place it in the label area in the advanced menus editor area: <https://app.HubSpot.com/menus/l/edit>
the only reason I can see this not working is something to do with the fact fm equals a function `{% set fm = follow_me_links() %}`
I’m going loopy over it.
:faceplam:  time to go home, the problem was the double = signs. how did I not notice I did that
haha
i just saw that too
JS on the brain
stared at this for almost 30 mins i swear
